text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to reach his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.

Why does he only take the elevator to the 7th floor on non-rainy days? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out why the man takes the elevator only to the 7th floor on non-rainy days.
Let me break this down step by step.
First, the man lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, regardless of the weather, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor, which is the 1st floor.
That makes sense because he's going to work, so he needs to go all the way down.
In the evening, when he returns home, things change based on the weather.
On rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way up to the 10th floor.
That's straightforward—probably because the stairs are slippery when it's raining, so he doesn't want to walk up the stairs.
But on non-rainy days, he takes the elevator only to the 7th floor and then walks up the remaining three floors.
Hmm, why would he do that? Let's think about the possible reasons.

Maybe the elevator is faster or more convenient up to the 7th floor, but why not go all the way? Perhaps the elevator is out of order, or maybe the man prefers to walk the last few floors for some reason.
But that doesn't seem to fit because on rainy days, he uses the elevator fully, which suggests that the elevator is functional and he's okay using it when needed.
Wait, another possibility is that the man wants to save money.
Maybe the elevator charges based on the floors traveled.
So, taking it to the 7th floor is cheaper than going all the way to the 10th floor.
That could be it.
If the elevator has a fare system where each floor has a certain cost, going only to the 7th floor would be cheaper than going to the 10th.
Hence, on non-rainy days, he takes the elevator part of the way and walks the rest to save money.
But on rainy days, he doesn't mind paying the higher fare because it's more convenient or he doesn't want to walk in the rain.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator is slower or less frequent after the 7th floor, so he prefers to walk the last three floors to save time.
But that doesn't align with him taking the elevator all the way on rainy days.
So, the cost explanation seems more plausible.
So, putting it all together, the man takes the elevator to the 7th floor on non-rainy days because it's cheaper than going all the way to the 10th floor.
He walks the remaining three floors because that's more economical for him.
On rainy days, he uses the elevator fully to avoid getting wet or because the cost isn't a concern when it's raining.
I think that's the main reason.
It all comes down to cost-saving behavior on non-rainy days.

</think>

The man takes the elevator only to the 7th floor on non-rainy days because it is cheaper than going all the way to the 10th floor.
He then walks up the remaining three floors to save money.
On rainy days, he uses the elevator fully to avoid getting wet, hence the different behavior.
